title: How to Make a Hearty Stew

steps.headline: Cut your beef chuck into small, 1-inch cubes.
steps.description: Although your beef cubes don't all need to have the same uniformity, it helps to try to be consistent. When cutting the beef chuck, remove any excess fat dangling from the outside of the cubes of meat. What if you don't have beef chuck? Rump, bottom round, or topside cuts will all do. What you want to avoid is getting pre-cut beef "for stewing" at the grocery store or market. You'll end up paying more and getting a lower quality meat.

steps.headline: Coat your beef in the all-purpose flour.
steps.description: In batches, transfer the beef cubes into a medium bowl containing the flour. Work the beef cubes into the flour so that each cube has a thin layer of flour coating its outside. This will give the beef a nice nutty flavor and great texture. It will also help establish a tasty "fond" on the bottom of your cooking pot. A fond is a sticky dark glaze that coats the bottom of the pan. It contributes to the rich, caramelized flavor that separates a merely good stew from a great one.

steps.headline: In a large Dutch oven or soup pot, begin searing the beef cubes over medium-high heat.
steps.description: First add 2 teaspoons of vegetable oil and the butter. Then, sear the beef in batches. Leave the beef on one side for 3 to 5 minutes, until it has developed great color and easily comes off the pan. Move it over to its side and brown on all sides. When a batch is done, remove beef with a slotted spoon and add the next batch. Continue cooking in the same manner as directed above, until all beef has been adequately browned. Do not clean the bowl after cooking the beef. You'll notice that your fond has started to develop. This fond will give your dish more of a full flavor, so don't make the mistake of removing it.

steps.headline: After removing beef from pot, start to cook the onions and celery over medium heat.
steps.description: Add the remaining teaspoon of vegetable oil and begin cooking the onions and celery over the fond created by the beef. Cook for 8 to 10 minutes, or until onions are soft and translucent, not browned.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and cook for about 30 seconds.
Add the tomato paste, a pinch of salt, and one tablespoon of the Worcestershire sauce to the onions and celery.
steps.description: Cook, stirring frequently, for 1 to 2 minutes, or until all tomato paste has been incorporated.

steps.headline: Deglaze the pan with 1 cup of red wine.
steps.description: Turn the heat back to medium-high and add the red wine. The wine should start steaming and bubbling up immediately. With a wooden spoon, scrape the bottom of the pan, breaking up the fond. Continue scraping and stirring until the wine has reduced somewhat.

steps.headline: Add the meat and stock to the pan.
Make a bouquet garni with the thyme, rosemary, and bay leaf, adding it into the stew.
steps.description: A bouquet garni is a simple way to hold your herbs and spices in one place, making removal simple after the stew is cooked. Simply put the herbs in cheesecloth and tie one end together with a length of string. Submerge the herb-end of the bouquet into the stew and tie the string to one of the pot's handles to make retrieval easy.

steps.headline: Cover your pot, reduce the heat to low, and simmer for 1 and 1/2 hours.
steps.description: Make sure the stew is simmering, not boiling. Stir the stew every so often.

steps.headline: Add the potatoes and carrots to the stew.
steps.description: Cover and cook for 40 to 60 minutes, stirring every so often. Carrots and potatoes are finished when a fork can easily puncture them.

steps.headline: Add the peas, Worcestershire, and a tiny bit of red wine to finish off the stew.
steps.description: Untie the bouquet garni and remove it from the pot. Taste and add any needed salt and pepper.

text: Cooking the Meat Cut your beef chuck into small, 1-inch cubes. Although your beef cubes don't all need to have the same uniformity, it helps to try to be consistent. When cutting the beef chuck, remove any excess fat dangling from the outside of the cubes of meat. What if you don't have beef chuck? Rump, bottom round, or topside cuts will all do. What you want to avoid is getting pre-cut beef "for stewing" at the grocery store or market. You'll end up paying more and getting a lower quality meat. Coat your beef in the all-purpose flour. In batches, transfer the beef cubes into a medium bowl containing the flour. Work the beef cubes into the flour so that each cube has a thin layer of flour coating its outside. This will give the beef a nice nutty flavor and great texture. It will also help establish a tasty "fond" on the bottom of your cooking pot. A fond is a sticky dark glaze that coats the bottom of the pan. It contributes to the rich, caramelized flavor that separates a merely good stew from a great one. In a large Dutch oven or soup pot, begin searing the beef cubes over medium-high heat. First add 2 teaspoons of vegetable oil and the butter. Then, sear the beef in batches. Leave the beef on one side for 3 to 5 minutes, until it has developed great color and easily comes off the pan. Move it over to its side and brown on all sides. When a batch is done, remove beef with a slotted spoon and add the next batch. Continue cooking in the same manner as directed above, until all beef has been adequately browned. Do not clean the bowl after cooking the beef. You'll notice that your fond has started to develop. This fond will give your dish more of a full flavor, so don't make the mistake of removing it. Adding the Vegetables After removing beef from pot, start to cook the onions and celery over medium heat. Add the remaining teaspoon of vegetable oil and begin cooking the onions and celery over the fond created by the beef. Cook for 8 to 10 minutes, or until onions are soft and translucent, not browned. Add the garlic and cook for about 30 seconds. Stir frequently during this time. Add the tomato paste, a pinch of salt, and one tablespoon of the Worcestershire sauce to the onions and celery. Cook, stirring frequently, for 1 to 2 minutes, or until all tomato paste has been incorporated. Deglaze the pan with 1 cup of red wine. Turn the heat back to medium-high and add the red wine. The wine should start steaming and bubbling up immediately. With a wooden spoon, scrape the bottom of the pan, breaking up the fond. Continue scraping and stirring until the wine has reduced somewhat. Add the meat and stock to the pan.  Make a bouquet garni with the thyme, rosemary, and bay leaf, adding it into the stew. A bouquet garni is a simple way to hold your herbs and spices in one place, making removal simple after the stew is cooked. Simply put the herbs in cheesecloth and tie one end together with a length of string. Submerge the herb-end of the bouquet into the stew and tie the string to one of the pot's handles to make retrieval easy. Finishing Your Stew Cover your pot, reduce the heat to low, and simmer for 1 and 1/2 hours. Make sure the stew is simmering, not boiling. Stir the stew every so often. Add the potatoes and carrots to the stew. Cover and cook for 40 to 60 minutes, stirring every so often. Carrots and potatoes are finished when a fork can easily puncture them. Add the peas, Worcestershire, and a tiny bit of red wine to finish off the stew. Untie the bouquet garni and remove it from the pot. Taste and add any needed salt and pepper. Serve.
